title: BREXIT BOOM: January surplus at 17-year HIGH in pre-budget boost for Hammond
text:
BREXIT BOOM: January surplus at 17-year HIGH in pre-budget boost for Hammond BREXIT BOOM: January surplus at 17-year HIGH in pre-budget boost for Hammond BRITAIN’S Brexit boom has seen the Government has record its highest January surplus for 17 years, new figures have revealed. PUBLISHED: 17:01,  22, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 GETTY The January surplus is at a 17-year high ahead of Philip hammond’s next budget 
In the latest sign that throwing of the shackles of Brussels rule is strengthening the economy, Chancellor Philip Hammond has £9.4 billion extra cash ahead of his Spring Budget. 
The surplus is up £300 million from January 2016 and is the results of the Government raking in tax receipts at the end of the self assessment period. 
It comes in stark contrast to the Project Fear strategy shaped by former Chancellor George Osborne for the Remain campaign in the EU referendum which claimed a Brexit vote would lead to an economic collapse. Related articles British finances had best January since 2000 amid economy boom 
The boost to the public finances came on a day with the FTSE 250 - seen as the main measure of the health of the economy - was up 17 points while the value of the pound climbed up against the euro and Japanese Yen. 
The figures also came as Government borrowing, excluding state owned banks, for the financial year to date - April to January - fell £13.6 billion to £49.3 billion, in contrast to the same 10 months in 2015. 
The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said it was the lowest year-to-date borrowing amount since January 2008. We remain committed to returning the public finances to balance Treasury spokesman 
A spokesman for the Treasury said: "We remain committed to returning the public finances to balance and building on our progress in reducing the deficit from 10 per cent to 4 per cent of GDP over the last six years. 
"Next month the Chancellor will deliver his Spring Budget based on updated forecasts from the Office of Budget Responsibility (OBR)." GETTY News of the surplus came on a day when the FTSE 250 gained 17 points 
Mr Hammond has ditched his predecessor's target of balancing the books by 2020, vowing instead to put the public finances back in the black "as early as possible" in the next Parliament as part of a new draft Charter for Budget Responsibility outlined in the Autumn Statement. 
In a gloomy prediction, the OBR - the Government's independent fiscal referee - said in November that it expects Mr Hammond to overshoot previous borrowing targets for this year, revising its outlook from £55.5 billion to £68.2 billion for 2016/17. Brexit: Which parts of the UK had the majority vote? Fri, February 17, 2017 Much of the North East of the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union including Sunderland, Gateshead, Darlington, Durham, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, Stockton, Redcar and Cleveland, North Tyneside and South Tyneside, and Northumberland. Newcastle was the only borough to vote to remain. Getty Images 1 of 8 GREAT YARMOUTH: The town of Great Yarmouth on the East Coast of England voted by 72% to leave the European Union. GETTY The figure has been seen as another sign of the financial success of Brexit 
However, economic think tank EY ITEM Club said on Monday that it expects Mr Hammond to receive a Budget boost, as the OBR unveils a brighter outlook on economic growth and the public finances. 
Britain's fiscal watchdog will trim back forecasts for net borrowing by £3 billion to £65 billion for 2016/2017, while changing predictions for the UK economy to 1.7 per cent from 1.4 per cent for this year, according to the organisation. 
It said the OBR will amend its outlook after seeing a bigger haul from tax receipts and a stronger performance from UK gross domestic product (GDP) in the fourth quarter of 2016. Related articles
